Suggested Questions

  • How do you find a mean average? (Add all the data and then divide by the number of data pieces.)
  • How can knowing how to find a mean average help to find Nishi's long-term average? (Add up all her points and then divide by 100)
  • How did we solve proportions in the Comparing and Scaling unit? (By finding a scale factor.)

Planning for the Summary

What evidence will you use in the Summary to clarify and deepen understanding of the Now What Do You Know? What will you do if you do not have evidence?

Now What Do You Know?

How is the long-term average calculated from the probabilities of outcomes for an event?

(Students will multiply each of the possible outcomes by the likelihood each outcome will occur and the add all of those values, then divide by the number of trials.)

Note: The expected value or long-term average only comes into play when the outcomes themselves have values beyond their probabilities.
